author: PowershellNinja
body:
Hi Powershell Team!

My boss visited a particular Powershell session at MS Ignite 2017 where a particular person said he would like a Pull Request containing the Remove-Alias Cmdlet.

We thought this would be a good point to start contributing to Powershell!

The PR contains the Remove-Alias Cmdlet and some tests for it (and a reference in the .psd1).
As this is my first contribution to Powershell I am looking forward to all thoughts, comments and suggestions, please tell me if there is anything I need to improve.

Regards,
Raphael

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: I don't think adding `Remove-Alias` should be an issue, but I'll bring it up today at the committee meeting.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: I'm good with it!

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @PowerShell/powershell-committee no concerns from PS-Committee on the addition of this cmdlet.  Thanks for the contribution!

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body: @iSazonov  Wow, thanks for all your feedback! I tried to incorporate it all in the last commit. Is there anything else I can / should do?

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body: Thanks for the additional suggestions, implemented them all. Are the empty lines between the tests and between the #region and parameter statements ok or should I remove them too?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
>Are the empty lines between the tests and between the #region and parameter statements ok or should I remove them too?

It is ok for new files. 
Main rule is - we must follow the pattern of the surrounding code to keep readability.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @adityapatwardhan @anmenaga Please review the PR.

comments.author: adityapatwardhan
comments.body: @PowershellNinja restarted the macOS build for Travis-CI.

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body: @adityapatwardhan Incorporated your suggestions. I was not sure what to put into the test names, are they ok like this?

comments.author: adityapatwardhan
comments.body: @PowershellNinja Please fix error in CI. https://ci.appveyor.com/project/PowerShell/powershell/build/6.0.0-beta.9-6380#L2444

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @PowershellNinja Please resolve merge conflict.

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body:
@iSazonov The conflict seems to be in DefaultCommands.Tests.ps1 and is caused by my addition of the Test for the "ral" alias. Do I have to remove it there now that I removed the Alias itself from "\src\System.Management.Automation\engine\InitialSessionState.cs"?
This is also the cause of the CI failing, the "ral" alias does not seem to work by just adding the [Alias()] attribute on the Cmdlet, do I need to add something else there?

comments.author: iSazonov
PowershellNinja
comments.body: @iSazonov Sorry, I think I did not clearly formulate that, thanks for taking care of the conflict. My question was not about the merge conflict, but about the fact that when I just have the "ral" alias added using the [Alias()] attribute on the Cmdlet, the alias does not seem to exist/work. Do you have any Idea why this might be?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @adityapatwardhan Can we merge without waiting CI MacOS?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@PowershellNinja Tests show that all works well. 
When you tried to add a _duplicate_ alias I believe the session initialization failed - both are in the same method, you got a broken environment.

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body: @iSazonov Ah I see, that may explain it. I retested with only one alias and all worked as expected.

comments.author: adityapatwardhan
comments.body: @PowershellNinja I restarted the macOS build and it passes now.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @PowershellNinja Please address the comment about tests and I'll merge.

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body: @iSazonov @JamesWTruher I implemented the suggestion about the tests in the latest commit

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @PowershellNinja Many thanks for your contribution! Welcome back with new PRs!

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body:
@iSazonov Awesome! Thanks all reviewers for your feedback and suggestions! I am looking forward to working on Powershell again in the future!

Von meinem iPhone gesendet

Am 03.11.2017 um 09:09 schrieb Ilya <notifications@github.com<mailto:notifications@github.com>>:


@PowershellNinja<https://github.com/powershellninja> Many thanks for your contribution! Welcome back with new PRs!

comments.author: jpsnover
comments.body: We should probably have a PSAnalyzer rule which warns people away from having ValueFromPipeline=TRUE on a STRING.  This is almost always the wrong thing to do.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
Do we expect the behavior? 
```powershell
gal E* |Select Name |Remove-aLias -Force
```

comments.author: PowershellNinja
comments.body:
@iSazonov I was able to reproduce this, as long as you use -Force, it removes the Aliases, without -Force it throws at the first removal because "ebp" is Read-Only:
```PowerShell
gal E* | Select Name
Name
----
ebp
echo
epal
epcsv
erase
etsn
exsn

gal E* | Select Name | Remove-Alias
Remove-Alias : Alias was not removed because alias ebp is constant or read-only.

gal E* | Select Name | Remove-Alias -Force
gal E* | Select Name
*Nothing Here*
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: We can easily fix this with try-catch and writing non-terminating error.

title: Add Remove-Alias Command
